items.content:
Hi Danielle,


So it seems like your client is interested in using Adobe to send web events and potentially audiences. 


We do have integrations through Adobe that cover sending web events through Events API as well as audiences.


Events API - https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/tags/extensions/server/tiktok/overview.html?lang=en

Audiences - https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/destinations/catalog/social/tiktok.html


We have an internal document that fully covers the Adobe integrations and can be accessed here: https://bytedance.us.larkoffice.com/docx/XynydX2a6ohEnDx26Geus0sksub


Please let me know if your client has any other questions. 


Regards,

Thomas

Since the Adobe integration is currently only Events API only, they have two options on how to implement:

  • Use existing Pixels and turn off/disable the current configuration. Since Adobe can only fire through Events API, if they continued to fire browser and/or server events through an older/existing configuration, it would likely be difficult to deduplicate the events. 
  • Use new Pixels specifically for the Adobe integration. This will prevent any impact on any existing Pixels and allow the Adobe integration to run by itself on a new Pixel. 


Regards,

Thomas
Thanks, Thomas! Will they need to update all their existing Pixels or if would they be good to just start fresh?

Hi Thomas,


Follow up questions from client:


"Since Events API is S2S pipeline, can you please confirm if cookie IDs from Safari (now) and Chrome (when they deprecate 3P cookies) are still captured through Events API data pipeline ?

 

And second question if Safari (and later on Chrome) are blocking 3P cookies from being passed through Events API /S2S, how other data attributes such as IP address and user agent still pass through the pipeline ? i.e. wouldn't both these data attributes be available only within the 3P browser cookie that are being blocked ?"

Hi Danielle,


So they are asking some pretty technical questions and it might be easier if you just add me to the email chain.

However, below are the answers to their questions:

  • Cookie IDs - these rely on the first party cookie set by the TikTok Browser Pixel's base code. The TikTok Browser Pixel automatically sets a first party cookie on page load and captures cookie IDs and ttclid (from ad impressions). The Adobe EAPI extension can then be configured to pass this value. 
  • IP/User Agent - these will rely on Adobe's datastream to capture/pass through. More information on the datastream can be found here: https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/datastreams/configure.html?lang=en
    • Once the datastream has been configured, the IP/User agent should be configurable in the "User Context Parameters" of the EAPI Extension: https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/tags/extensions/server/tiktok/overview.html


Regards,

Thomas
Amazing!! Will do that in case they have further questions - thanks, Thomas :)

Client had follow up questions on 3-11:

Hi Danielle,

The Cookie IDs that would be passed are going to be first party cookie? EAPI tagging would NOT pass 3rd party cookies ?

 

Thank you,

Alex


---


Responded on 3-12:

Hi Alexandra,

It seems you have a question regarding how Events API captures and passes data from a cookie. 

  • The EAPI does not have the ability to pass back an actual cookie. It can only access values stored in a cookie i.e. A first party cookie set by the TikTok browser Pixel 
  • The values that the Pixel and EAPI capture are primarily cookie ID and click ID
  • We do not capture data from any other cookies
  • Some more info on TikTok cookies can be found here: https://ads.tiktok.com/help/article/using-cookies-with-tiktok-pixel?lang=en

Please let me know if you have any additional questions or concerns. 

Thomas

Follow up questions from the client on March 12-

Hi Thomas,

Thank you for sharing.

If the TikTok browser Pixel set as a first party cookie and Events API is accessing to information that browser Pixel store, can you please share what are the benefits would bring Events API tag  to already enabled  browser Pixel.

As I understand browser Pixel need to be always enabled  and Events API tag is addons to it, and Events API cannot be enabled by itself, please correct me if I am wrong.

 

Thank you,

Alex


-- 

My response via email on March 13th:

Hi Alexandra,


Answers to your questions below:

"what are the benefits would bring Events API tag  to already enabled  browser Pixel." 

  • On average, our advertisers see a 15% improvement in CPA when going from a browser only setup to a dual channel setup. 

"As I understand browser Pixel need to be always enabled  and Events API tag is addons to it, and Events API cannot be enabled by itself, please correct me if I am wrong." 

  • The Adobe <> TikTok EAPI integration does rely on a TikTok browser Pixel to pass Cookie ID and click ID via a first party cookie. You may still use the EAPI integration without a browser Pixel, but it would result in a loss of the aforementioned parameters which do bring significant value in terms of user matching and advertising efficiency. 
  • There are potential paths to an Events API/Server only signals setup. There are some additional steps needed to fully replace the functionality of the Browser Pixel in that type of setup as our Events API was designed to work in tandem with a Browser Pixel. 
  • There are advertisers who choose to go this route for various reasons, including future proofing and a desire for increased data security. If this is something you are interested in exploring, please let me know and I am happy to provide you with some implementation options for a server only setup. 


Regards,

Thomas

Hi Thomas,


Would it be beneficial for us to set up a call with this team to chat through? Feel like they may understand more if we chat directly with them.

Let me know what you think!



Thank you,

danielle

Hi Danielle,


Has the client requested a call? It seems they are content to have their questions addressed by email so far. 


Thomas

Client had additional questions: 

Hi Thomas,

But in terms of 3rd party  cookies deprecation will Events API tag  can bring any benefit on that or there is any other solution?

 

Thank you,

Alex


---


Addressed via email on 3-14:

Hi Alexandra,

TikTok's Events API does not utilize third party cookies. The potential deprecation of third party cookies should not affect the signal quality of an Events API integration. 

More info can be found on this page: https://ads.tiktok.com/help/article/using-cookies-with-tiktok-pixel?lang=en

Please let me know if you have any additional questions. 

Regards,

Thomas

Client had additional questions on March 18th:

Hi Tomas,

I hope you had a great weekend.

Thank you for sharing its all really helpful info, but I still have some additional questions.

TikTok currently connect to Google's PA API or planning to connect sometime this year ?

If not, would Events API solution work for retargeting for traffic that is not coming from ad clicks (i.e. view-through traffic) ?

After chrome deprecates 3P cookies, can Events API work for view-through real-time conversion optimization without hashed email/phone data or would it only be available for click-through traffic ?


---


Addressed via email on March 19th:

Hi Alexandra,

Answers to your questions below:

  • TikTok connecting to Google's Protected Audience API - from reading the link you provided this seems to be a solution that Google is providing directly to advertisers. I do not believe they would enable the API for platforms like TikTok. 
  • Events API solution work for retargeting for traffic that is not coming from ad clicks (i.e. view-through traffic) - Yes, data from Events API does provide value for organic traffic. This is assuming we have enough parameters to perform matching. We are able to match based on data such as ip address, user agent, external ID, email/phone (where available) and of course click ID. With enough events, our algorithm is able to make matches to users based on some combination of the aforementioned parameters. 
  • After chrome deprecates 3P cookies, can Events API work for view-through real-time conversion optimization without hashed email/phone data or would it only be available for click-through traffic ? In the absence of hashed user data, we would still be able to attribute conversions (including view through) using a combination of the other parameters (IP, user agent, external ID, etc.) Chrome's deprecation of 3P cookies should not have an effect on Events API performance as we do not utilize or collect data from 3rd party cookies through that channel. 

Regards,

Thomas

items.content:
TD is considering moving from Pixel to Events API, and also looking at using Adobe audiences.
They have a question regarding the above in the adobe resources...

"would you have documentation that support that integration through Adobe Launch? I see many other platforms in the partners list doc but I do not see Adobe in it.

I was able to find on Adobe info about TikTok extension but please can you confirm if we can correspond to it https://experienceleague.adobe.com/docs/experience-platform/destinations/catalog/social/tiktok.html?lang=en if you have any other sources please share.

It says that it recommended to send events through browser and through Event API, would you be able to share list of already created pixels that implemented through browser and conversion point for them? My assumption that we would need to implement that list of existed pixels through Event API functionality, please correct me if I am missing something."

Sharing screenshot they shared with us of what they are referring to
